channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Shane Warne, one of the greatest cricket players of all time, and a larger-than-life figure on and off the field, died Friday in Thailand. He was 52. https://t.co/YI69MS2WGz https://t.co/PoWaJzaGHm

Russia passed a law Friday punishing the spreading of "false information" about Russia’s forces with as much as 15 years in prison. The law could make a criminal offense of simply calling the war a "war" and will take effect as soon as Saturday. https://t.co/y2EwoNyeOd
Videos verified by The New York Times reveal the scale of the devastation of civilian areas in Kharkiv, Ukraine, after days of Russian bombardment. https://t.co/WeeERIFiI4
Breaking News: Hiring in the U.S. sped up in February, with employers adding 678,000 jobs, as falling Covid cases brought customers and workers back. https://t.co/dgGKj7UZM4

Breaking News: The Russian government has blocked access to Facebook inside the country. It’s the latest instance of the Kremlin’s far-reaching campaign to clamp down on dissent in the wake of the invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/TVpeV1fvv9

NATO foreign ministers rejected any possibility of intervening against Russian forces in Ukraine, whether on the ground or in the air, the alliance’s secretary general said Friday. https://t.co/TjnFT8sDAz
Breaking News: The Supreme Court reinstated the death sentence of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted of helping carry out the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings. https://t.co/zJbrwjltl7

Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has galvanized NATO’s 30 member states to assist “in one way or another,” Secretary of State Antony Blinken said at NATO headquarters on Friday. https://t.co/uAnN0OmrIy https://t.co/VnRNpP80cG

Breaking News: At least 57 people were killed and more than 100 wounded after an explosion tore through a Shiite mosque in Pakistan. The attack was most likely carried out by the region’s Islamic State affiliate, officials said. https://t.co/0aHohb2IUx

NATO rejected Ukraine’s pleas to establish a no-fly zone over the country, its secretary general said. The alliance has resisted such a move for fear that it could draw member states into the war. https://t.co/bb2gqIoj7f https://t.co/mYXAsLEs72

Many African leaders are sitting out the global outcry over Russia's invasion of Ukraine, reluctant to criticize a country that supported their liberation struggles and is still a source of trade, education and arms. https://t.co/UNeP7MaVrA

The UN Human Rights Council voted decisively to set up an international tribunal to investigate possible war crimes and human rights violations in Ukraine. Russia dismissed the resolution as a waste of resources. https://t.co/BmJaDILChq
Ukrainian troops are fighting with a resourcefulness and creativity that U.S. analysts said could trip up Russian troops for weeks or months to come. https://t.co/zEVdbXP6TV

Two Russian nationals flying in a private jet that had taken off from Geneva landed in Canada this week and were stopped from traveling farther, Canadian officials said.
Canada had announced on Sunday that it would ban Russian aircraft from its airspace. https://t.co/pYoKTNOoWA

People looking to leave Russia have started packing trains destined for Finland.
“We’ve had full trains from St. Petersburg from Sunday onward,” a Finnish Railways official said. “They are leaving for good.” https://t.co/FVYXtmd5c9

Surprised by the speed at which sanctions have been poured on Russia, top U.S. officials are concerned that President Vladimir Putin’s reaction will be to double down and lash out — and perhaps expand the war beyond Ukraine. https://t.co/uWkSVFeV85

The Ukrainian Navy purposely sank the flagship of its Black Sea fleet on Thursday to prevent the warship from being seized by the Russian military, Ukraine’s defense minister said. https://t.co/PWHmR3zLJ2

Russian troops seized Zaporizhzhia, Europe’s largest nuclear power plant, Ukrainian officials said, hours after a fire broke out at the complex during the assault. There was no sign that radiation had leaked, international monitors said.
Follow updates. https://t.co/yMYAR3mfs2 https://t.co/GaeF8eALsA

Viral stories like the Ghost of Kyiv — a Ukrainian pilot who supposedly single-handedly shot down several Russian fighter jets — are of questionable veracity. But they're a key part of Ukraine's war plan, experts say, as it tries to keep morale high. https://t.co/oNUZArrGUy
A 19-year-old testified against his father in a trial related to the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol. https://t.co/OoSFG4WWLi

The Biden administration announced on Thursday it would offer humanitarian relief to Ukrainians who have been living in the country without legal documentation since March 1 or earlier, signaling additional support for citizens of Ukraine. https://t.co/5Rf1iUa5BX
Ukrainian troops are fighting with a resourcefulness and creativity that U.S. analysts said could trip up Russian troops for weeks or months to come. https://t.co/3d2zZXpvTa

Google said on Thursday night that it had suspended all advertising in Russia after the country’s internet regulator demanded that the company stop showing what it considered ads displaying false information about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/r0vzDp4Pu3

A convoy of Russian supply trucks and attack vehicles headed for Kyiv, "has made little discernible progress in over three days," Britain’s defense ministry said, "having been delayed by staunch Ukrainian resistance, mechanical breakdown and congestion." https://t.co/lmwh83m5Ba

A former Fox News producer was charged with violating U.S. sanctions by working for a Russian oligarch who has been accused of being a leading financial supporter of separatists in Crimea and eastern Ukraine and has close ties to President Vladimir Putin. https://t.co/wb9tyM3zJs

Medical students at a university in Sumy, Ukraine, saw their school become a war zone overnight. They have no way to travel home and are hoping that authorities can create a safe corridor for them to evacuate. https://t.co/xHOwyhWa0d https://t.co/bU0D8c5gPk
In a legal filing, the Jan. 6 panel laid out a narrative aimed at showing that Donald Trump knew the 2020 election was not stolen. https://t.co/xydMJ5sEqU

“We have a special people, an extraordinary people,” President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said on Thursday at his first news conference since the war began.
Zelensky’s defiance has made him a symbol of Ukraine’s resistance to the Russian invasion.
https://t.co/Ba5mWOOXP5

A fire broke out early Friday morning at a complex in southern Ukraine that is home to Europe’s largest nuclear power plant, after Russian troops fired on the area, Ukraine’s foreign minister said.
Follow our live updates. https://t.co/L1Ph1KXHmD

More than 800 medical students are stranded at their university in the city of Sumy in northeastern Ukraine, officials said, after Russian forces hindered access to roads and trains. The students are mostly from African countries and India. https://t.co/d0VTAgAdTW

A phone conversation between President Emmanuel Macron and President Vladimir Putin on Thursday offered little hope that the fighting in Ukraine would abate soon. The French president's office warned that Putin seems determined to invade the whole country. https://t.co/r3b02RMwVE

Ikea and TJX, the owner of TJ Maxx and Marshalls, became the latest retailers to halt business operations in Russia, joining the growing number of Western companies condemning the country’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/n7ePLY1DHl

The U.S. has announced an array of new sanctions on Russian elites and oligarchs, including President Vladimir Putin’s spokesman. The sanctions include travel bans and seizures of assets. https://t.co/QfueP2EmKe

Ukrainians fleeing Russia’s invasion of their country will be offered temporary protection in the European Union, its ministers decided on Thursday, as the exodus from Ukraine surpassed a million people. https://t.co/A8aBLcG35E https://t.co/4vhmpI0kxT
Breaking News: The Biden administration is offering temporary protected status to Ukrainians who were living in the U.S. without documentation as of March 1. https://t.co/xv2CVLxbd8

Flag manufacturers across the U.S. are cutting and sewing blue and yellow fabric as fast as possible to keep up with the surge in demand for the flag of Ukraine since the country was invaded by Russia last week. https://t.co/z4sr4lnSyF
The International Chess Federation is working to distance itself from Russia, canceling tournaments and disqualifying grandmasters who support the invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/hWbQv48gxq

One million Ukrainians have become refugees in the week since Russian forces invaded, the UN said, and another million people have been displaced or are on the move inside the country. https://t.co/ZlyGriRfBn https://t.co/mSXfhblDOa

President Vladimir Putin for the first time personally acknowledged Russian losses in the war in Ukraine in a video televised on Russian state media on Thursday. He also claimed the military operation was proceeding according to plan.
Follow live updates: https://t.co/NGBxrYwszM https://t.co/FMX2Gkm4RJ

The BBC is reviving its use of shortwave radio to broadcast in Ukraine and in parts of Russia. The tactic, popularized during World War II, uses frequencies that can travel for long distances and be accessible on portable radios. https://t.co/kAT4fvWUjB
Hundreds of people waited in long lines for food in Kharkiv as Ukraine warned of a humanitarian crisis caused by Russia’s invasion. https://t.co/WSF413VC1l https://t.co/jwlsQZBT66

Russians aren't getting enough accurate information about the invasion of Ukraine to really understand it, @kadriliik told @EllenBarryNYT. Listen to the conversation: https://t.co/1tYJEIsbvW https://t.co/qxLVs20RwF

The U.S. surgeon general formally requested that big tech platforms provide information about the scale of Covid misinformation on their sites.
The notice asked for details of “exactly how many users saw or may have been exposed to” Covid misinformation. https://t.co/cdHuNkGfwz

The Ukrainian military is conducting a hugely effective and "mobile" defense, using their innate knowledge of their home turf to stymie Russian forces on multiple fronts, the top military adviser to President Biden said early Thursday. https://t.co/8yxOoqGMaR

Breaking News: The Russian soprano Anna Netrebko won’t sing at the Metropolitan Opera for at least two seasons after the company demanded she distance herself from Vladimir Putin. https://t.co/N0K36XOPHM

The Biden administration is preparing more sanctions aimed at Russian oligarchs as the U.S. seeks to put more pressure on Russia’s economy and allies of President Vladimir Putin, a person familiar with the plans said. https://t.co/EeBewqQsOL

Video verified by The New York Times shows the bombardment of Chernihiv, Ukraine, on Thursday. As smoke cleared from the attack — which hit near apartments, pharmacies and a hospital — people are seen running in the street. https://t.co/J1MhFcNCnm https://t.co/S2l2MBkxaF

Video verified by The New York Times shows two warplanes flying at low altitude moments before launching an airstrike on an apartment complex in a city just outside Kyiv on Wednesday. The Ukrainian police said it was not yet clear if there were casualties. https://t.co/2JeCVcJMr1

A 28-year-old man was arrested and charged with committing hate crimes in a two-hour spree of attacks on seven women of Asian descent in Manhattan over the weekend. The attacks were another example of a grim wave of violence against Asian Americans. https://t.co/ABN59Gves4

Ukrainians are facing a deepening humanitarian crisis as Russian forces bombard urban areas, reducing basic services to rubble.
A million people have become refugees in the past week, the UN said, as packed evacuation trains carry them west. https://t.co/6SSljyqY1Z https://t.co/P6xd6HpHMl
